results.headline: Permafrost Makes the Heart Grow Stranger in a Haunted Snow Globe

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Winnipeg

results.summary_short: “My Winnipeg,” which combines archival documentary images with freshly shot passages, is more concerned with lyrical truth than with literal accuracy.

results.headline: World-Weary Fantasy

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Warsaw Bridge

results.summary_short: “Warsaw Bridge,” which takes place mostly in Barcelona and is directed by Pere Portabella, is not shy about declaring a debt to Buñuelian surrealism.

results.headline: The Cycle of Seasons Illuminated

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Blue Planet

results.summary_short: I take no pleasure in dumping on a 25-year-old pseudo-experimental nature documentary, but neither did I find much to like in “Blue Planet.”

results.headline: The Mingling of Dreams and Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Love Comes Lately

results.summary_short: Max Kohn (Otto Tausig), the aging Lothario of “Love Comes Lately,” is very much like the movie itself: doddering and milquetoasty, but ultimately disarming.

results.headline: Homeless but Hopeful

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kicking It

results.summary_short: So earnest it hurts, “Kicking It” follows a half-dozen homeless men from around the globe as they ready for the fourth annual Homeless World Cup in Cape Town.

results.headline: A Femme Fatale Who Finds Mystery and Eroticism in a Wheelchair

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Quid Pro Quo

results.summary_short: “Quid Pro Quo” hovers in a noir-shaded twilight zone where repressed memories and guilt merge in an obsession with physical and emotional paralysis.

results.headline: Mighty Climbers

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of To the Limit

results.summary_short: In “To the Limit,” Thomas and Alexander Huber run up rocks the way some of us run up credit cards — rapidly, fearlessly and with little regard for consequences.

results.headline: Caution: Contents Turn Angry When Shaken

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Incredible Hulk

results.summary_short: The new movie about Dr. Bruce Banner is called “The Incredible Hulk.” But let’s not get carried away: “The Adequate Hulk” would have been a more suitable title.

results.headline: Something Lethal Lurks in the Rustling Trees

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Happening

results.summary_short: “The Happening” is a divertingly goofy thriller with an animistic bent, moments of shivery and twitchy suspense and a solid lead performance from Mark Wahlberg.

results.headline: How Many Goodly Creatures Are There on Mr. Herzog’s Planet
results.display_title: Encounters at the End of the World

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Encounters at the End of the World

results.summary_short: Few filmmakers make the end of days seem as hauntingly beautiful as Werner Herzog does in “Encounters at the End of the World.”

results.headline: Clips From an Artistic Life, Provocative and Cinematic

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Derek

results.summary_short: This fragmentary portrait of the British filmmaker, painter, set designer and writer Derek Jarman, is a cinematic scrapbook of the life and times of an iconoclast, aesthete and provocateur.

results.headline: Fresh Produce for Ratatouille, Please, but No Attitude

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Grocer's Son

results.summary_short: “The Grocer’s Son” is a French variation of the fable of the prodigal son.

results.headline: Supernatural Stew, Served With Camp

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mother of Tears

results.summary_short: “The Mother of Tears” is silly, awkward, vulgar, outlandish, hysterical, inventive, revolting, flamboyant, titillating, ridiculous, priceless, tasteless and sublime.

results.headline: Fuzzy Outsider, Kicking His Way Toward His Dream

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kung Fu Panda

results.summary_short: At once fuzzy-wuzzy and industrial strength, the tacky-sounding “Kung Fu Panda” is high concept with a heart.

results.headline: A Tall Order

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Take Out

results.summary_short: “Take Out” tracks, with nimble attention and fine curiosity, a day in the life of an illegal Chinese immigrant as he darts around Upper Manhattan on a cheap bicycle.

results.headline: Songs of Africa

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of On the Rumba River

results.summary_short: You don’t have to be a fan of African tunes to appreciate Jacques Sarasin’s heartfelt ode to Congolese music and its resilient practitioners.

results.headline: The Clues and Conspiracies of an Assassination
results.display_title: RFK Must Die: The Assassination Of Bobby Kennedy

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of RFK Must Die: The Assassination Of Bobby Kennedy

results.summary_short: Heads talk and reason walks in this conspiracy-addled trudge through the Ambassador Hotel’s most fateful event.

results.headline: Forge a Unity of Purpose, Then Conquer the World

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mongol

results.summary_short: “Mongol” is a big, ponderous epic, its beautifully composed landscape shots punctuated by thundering hooves and bloody, slow-motion battle sequences.

results.headline: Lessons of the Road, With Phone

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Go-Getter

results.summary_short: The 19-year-old protagonist of Martin Hynes’s wispy but appealing film “The Go-Getter” travels a long and winding road.

results.headline: As a Father Nears Death, a Son Grows No Closer
results.display_title: When Did You Last See Your Father?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of When Did You Last See Your Father?

results.summary_short: “When Did You Last See Your Father?” is grown-up, civilized fare, even though the whole thing might have been improved with a bit of messiness.
